title: Engine Management System Actuators

body.body: In response to signals received from the sensors, the engine ECM controls and directs messages to a series of electronic and electromechanical actuators. The function and location of the actuators is given below.
Eng Mngt Actuators PB1; PJ1; PJZ

- situated on the front of the throttle bodies. The throttle actuator motor opens and closes the throttle plates in the throttle bodies, in response to commands from the ECM. The throttle actuator motor is an integral part of the throttle bodies.

- situated in the vapour return line between the carbon canister and the throttle bodies. The purge valve controls the return of vapour which has been stored in the carbon canister during the period when the engine is switched off. The valve is pulsed by the engine ECM to give control over the rate at which the canister is purged.

- located on the throttle body. The engine is fitted with three fuel injectors. The spray pattern of the injector is fixed but the length of time each injector can remain open is variable according to operating conditions. The duration of each injection is calculated by the engine ECM using data received from the various sensors in the system.

- plug-top coils are located in the camshaft cover. There are three coils fitted, one for each spark plug. The engine ECM controls the point at which the coils are switched on and off. In calculating the switch-on time, the engine ECM allows sufficient time for the coils to charge to a level where a spark can be produced. The coils are switched off at the point of ignition, the timing of which is optimised for good engine performance.

- situated behind the battery. When the ignition is switched on, the EMS main relay is powered up to provide a stable Voltage supply for the engine ECM. When the ignition is turned off, the engine ECM carries out a power down sequence during which the EMS main relay remains powered by the engine ECM for 1 minute. The engine ECM power down sequence includes: writing the adaption data to engine ECM memory and referencing the position of the throttle stepper motor.

- situated on the right hand side of the motorcycle above the exhaust intermediate silencer. Exhaust butterfly valve actuator motor controls the exhaust butterfly valve which part of the exhaust intermediate silencer. The valve is closed at idle and starts to open at 5000 rpm. At 6000 rpm the valve is 50% and is fully open at 7000 rpm. This is the same in all gears and does not vary with throttle input.
- located inside the fuel tank. The electric pump delivers fuel into the fuel system, via a pressure regulator, at a constant

pressure. The pump is run continuously when the engine is operating and is also run briefly when the ignition is first switched on to ensure that full pressure is available to the system as soon as the engine is cranked. Fuel pressure is controlled by a regulator also situated inside the fuel tank.

- located behind the radiators. The engine ECM controls switching on and off of the cooling fans in response to a signal received from the coolant temperature sensor. When the coolant temperature rises to a level where the cooling effect of natural airflow is insufficient, the cooling fans are turned on by the engine ECM. When the coolant temperature falls sufficiently, the engine ECM turns the cooling fans off. The fans only becomes operational when the engine is running. It will not operate at any other time.
- located above the camshaft cover. The secondary air injection solenoid controls airflow through the secondary air injection system.
In this system, the starter lockout system (clutch switch, gear position sensor, side stand switch) all operate through the engine ECM.

In response to signals received from the sensors, the engine ECM controls and directs messages to a series of electronic and electromechanical actuators. The function and location of the actuators is given below.
Throttle actuator motor

- situated on the front of the throttle bodies. The throttle actuator motor opens and closes the throttle plates in the throttle bodies, in response to commands from the ECM. The throttle actuator motor is an integral part of the throttle bodies.
Canister purge valve (certain markets only)

- situated in the vapour return line between the carbon canister and the throttle bodies. The purge valve controls the return of vapour which has been stored in the carbon canister during the period when the engine is switched off. The valve is pulsed by the engine ECM to give control over the rate at which the canister is purged.
Fuel injectors

- located on the throttle body. The engine is fitted with three fuel injectors. The spray pattern of the injector is fixed but the length of time each injector can remain open is variable according to operating conditions. The duration of each injection is calculated by the engine ECM using data received from the various sensors in the system.
Ignition coils

- plug-top coils are located in the camshaft cover. There are three coils fitted, one for each spark plug. The engine ECM controls the point at which the coils are switched on and off. In calculating the switch-on time, the engine ECM allows sufficient time for the coils to charge to a level where a spark can be produced. The coils are switched off at the point of ignition, the timing of which is optimised for good engine performance.
Engine Management System (EMS) main relay

- situated behind the battery. When the ignition is switched on, the EMS main relay is powered up to provide a stable Voltage supply for the engine ECM. When the ignition is turned off, the engine ECM carries out a power down sequence during which the EMS main relay remains powered by the engine ECM for 1 minute. The engine ECM power down sequence includes: writing the adaption data to engine ECM memory and referencing the position of the throttle stepper motor.
Exhaust Butterfly Valve Actuator Motor

- situated on the right hand side of the motorcycle above the exhaust intermediate silencer. Exhaust butterfly valve actuator motor controls the exhaust butterfly valve which part of the exhaust intermediate silencer. The valve is closed at idle and starts to open at 5000 rpm. At 6000 rpm the valve is 50% and is fully open at 7000 rpm. This is the same in all gears and does not vary with throttle input.
Fuel pump
- located inside the fuel tank. The electric pump delivers fuel into the fuel system, via a pressure regulator, at a constant
3.5 bar

pressure. The pump is run continuously when the engine is operating and is also run briefly when the ignition is first switched on to ensure that full pressure is available to the system as soon as the engine is cranked. Fuel pressure is controlled by a regulator also situated inside the fuel tank.
Cooling fans

- located behind the radiators. The engine ECM controls switching on and off of the cooling fans in response to a signal received from the coolant temperature sensor. When the coolant temperature rises to a level where the cooling effect of natural airflow is insufficient, the cooling fans are turned on by the engine ECM. When the coolant temperature falls sufficiently, the engine ECM turns the cooling fans off. The fans only becomes operational when the engine is running. It will not operate at any other time.
Secondary air injection solenoid
- located above the camshaft cover. The secondary air injection solenoid controls airflow through the secondary air injection system.
In this system, the starter lockout system (clutch switch, gear position sensor, side stand switch) all operate through the engine ECM.
